gameDetails.venue: Amon G. Carter Stadium, Fort Worth, TX

situationalFactors.homeField: TCU undefeated at home (5-0) entering game
situationalFactors.revenge: Iowa State embarrassed TCU 42-14 in Ames last season
situationalFactors.offensiveTempo: TCU's up-tempo offense averaged 82.3 plays/game at home
situationalFactors.iowaStateRoadRecord: Cyclones 2-3 in true road games with losses by 10, 7, 3

keyFactors.title: Home Dominance
keyFactors.description: TCU entered 5-0 at Amon G. Carter Stadium with average margin of victory of 15.6 points. Home crowd created significant advantage for up-tempo offense.

keyFactors.title: Offensive Firepower
keyFactors.description: TCU averaged 38.4 PPG at home vs 28.1 on road. QB Josh Hoover threw for 2,847 yards with 24 TDs and just 6 INTs at home over last 2 seasons.

keyFactors.title: Iowa State Secondary Struggles
keyFactors.description: Cyclones ranked 89th in pass defense efficiency, allowing 8.2 yards/attempt in Big 12 road games. TCU's air raid offense designed to exploit this weakness.

keyFactors.title: Revenge Motivation
keyFactors.description: TCU still angry from 42-14 blowout loss in Ames last November. Revenge games historically cover at 58% rate when home team has offense advantage.

riskFactors: Iowa State's ball-control offense could limit TCU possessions
TCU's defense ranked 72nd nationally - vulnerable to clock management
Weather conditions (30 mph winds) could disrupt passing game

scoringBreakdown.description: TCU TD 7-0 - Fast start for Horned Frogs. 4-play, 75-yard TD drive in 1:42. Josh Hoover 38-yard TD strike.
ISU FG 7-3, TCU FG 10-3, ISU TD 10-10 - Iowa State responded with methodical drives. Cyclones tied game on 14-play, 7:18 TD drive consuming clock. Half: 10-10.
ISU FG 10-13, TCU FG 13-13 - Defensive struggle. Both teams exchanged FGs. Iowa State dominated TOP 9:22 to 5:38.

ISU TD 13-20, TCU FG 17-20 - DISASTER. TCU fumbled at ISU 23-yard line while driving for go-ahead TD. Iowa State responded with game-winning 12-play, 6:47 TD drive. TCU's last-second FG attempt from 52 yards fell short. Final: 20-17.

gameResults.whenCleared: Never covered - lost outright by 3 points
gameResults.gamePace: Iowa State controlled tempo completely - 36:12 time of possession (60.3%). TCU's up-tempo offense neutralized by ball control.

whatWentWrong.title: Catastrophic Turnovers
whatWentWrong.description: TCU committed 3 turnovers (2 fumbles, 1 INT) vs Iowa State's 0. Most devastating: fumble at ISU 23-yard line in Q4 while driving for potential go-ahead TD. 10-point swing.

whatWentWrong.title: Time of Possession Massacre
whatWentWrong.description: Iowa State held ball for 36:12 (60.3%) vs TCU's 23:48. Cyclones ran 78 plays vs TCU's 61. Up-tempo offense completely neutralized by ball control.

whatWentWrong.title: Rushing Defense Collapse
whatWentWrong.description: Iowa State rushed for 244 yards on 52 carries (4.7 YPC). TCU's 72nd-ranked defense couldn't stop ground game, allowing 7+ minute drives repeatedly.

whatWentWrong.title: Red Zone Failures
whatWentWrong.description: TCU went 1-for-4 in red zone (1 TD, 2 FGs, 1 fumble). Iowa State went 2-for-3 (2 TDs, 1 FG). Red zone efficiency 5-point swing directly decided outcome.

statisticalContext.vsSpread: Lost by 10.5 points vs -7.5 line (failed to cover by 150%)
statisticalContext.vsProjection: TCU scored 21.4 below home average (38.4 PPG), Iowa State scored 3.3 above road avg
statisticalContext.turnoverImpact: -3 turnover margin = approximately -10.5 expected point swing
statisticalContext.percentileRanking: 8th percentile offensive performance for TCU at home

closingLineValue.verdict: Slight positive CLV - line held steady despite public money on TCU home favorite. Market correctly priced Iowa State's ball-control threat.

lessonsLearned: Up-tempo offenses vulnerable to ball-control opponents who limit possessions
Turnover margin (-3) is nearly impossible to overcome regardless of home field advantage
Red zone efficiency matters more than total yardage - TCU outgained ISU 342-389 but went 1-for-4 in RZ
72nd-ranked defense is fatal flaw when opponent commits 0 turnovers and controls clock
Weather conditions (30 mph winds) disrupted TCU's passing attack (Hoover 23-of-38, 60.5%)
whatCouldHaveChanged: If TCU doesn't fumble at ISU 23-yard line in Q4 → likely TCU 24, ISU 13 (covers)
If TCU converts even 2-of-4 red zone trips instead of 1-of-4 → likely TCU 24-27 (covers)
If TCU's defense forces even 1 turnover → completely changes time of possession battle
verdict: Analytically sound pre-game case crushed by execution failures. Turnovers, red zone inefficiency, and time of possession dominance created perfect storm. Iowa State's game plan (ball control + 0 turnovers) was textbook.
